description: Typical spin and move board game from 1930's. The player first succeeding in moving his Mice into the Mouses' Home again in the order stated, by exact spins of the arrow, win the game.

Swords and Heroes is a unique, history-based tactical game that allows players the opportunity to battle some of the greatest armies in history. The flagship game of the independent company ZAMA Game Design, Swords and Heroes challenges players in a simple-yet-engaging combat system.

The game uses a detailed “Cards and Shards” system that uses board-based tactical “shards” to represent battlefield units of the respective armies. Basic statistics and abilities of these units are represented by beautifully-designed game cards held by each player. Units range from light-armored infantry to long-ranged archers or heavy cavalry, but vary wildly based on the historical civilization chosen by the player.

After custom-designing their armies using a simple point-based creation mechanic, players field their armies and face off for the control of the board with easy-to-learn dice-based turn mechanics. Players also make use of “General’s Orders” cards that offer players powerful and unique means of shifting the course of battle. Once the enemy has been eliminated from the board, the remaining general stands victorious!

The Swords and Heroes: Starter Set comes with all of the necessary rules and game components required, as well as two Classical Age armies: The Roman Empire and the Germanic Tribes. Future expansion packs will also offer players additional armies, such as Han China, Alexander’s Macedonia, Parthian Persia, and more!

Game description from the publisher:

In the dice-rolling race game Railways Express, 2-4 players travel around the USA and through parts of southern Canada and northern Mexico, building track as in the related Railways of the World game series from their individual starting city across plains, waterways and mountains based upon what they roll on the two terrain dice and two track dice.

By linking cities with track, you are awarded re-roll cubes (and possibly cards), which gives strategic options for the routes available to you as you try to connect more cities. If you're the first player to link all four cities of your color, you win!

A fast action family word game for one or more players.

The object of the game is to form as many vertical and horizontal words as possible within 6 minutes... or whatever time limit the players wish to set.

On each turn, a player starts the timer, then randomly draws cubes from the bag one at a time. Each cube may be turned to any desired letter, and is then placed into any open square in the board. Once placed, letter cubes may not be moved or turned again. When the timer runs out, or the last letter is placed, the player's turn is over and his score is calculated for both horizontal and vertical words in the grid.

Players act simutanously and take and try to match the colored tiles from the middle of the table on their boards.

Who was able to place first all correct tiles on his board is the winner.

50 x tricky mysteries about knightly orders, mighty kings, scary castle keeps, trojan horses, holy grails, golden Amber Rooms, illustrious damsels of the castle and the gold of the Aztecs. The players try to reconstruct the stories by asking, guessing and fiddling about. Only yes/no answers are allowed. A card game just right for any party.

Build a small empire in a land of legends!

Eight-Minute Empire: Legends is a standalone sequel to the area control game Eight-Minute Empire and does not require the original game to play. Just like the original game, players take turns selecting a card from six on display. The card has an action that the player takes immediately, and actions help players take over the map – but what's new and different in this version?


    Instead of goods, cards now have special abilities, which give players unique advantages and ways to break the rules throughout the game
    Each card has a unique, beautiful illustration of a fantasy creature or location
    A modular board for increased variety
    New variants


Is Eight-Minute Empire: Legends still playable in eight minutes? Yes, but only if you hurry!

Eight-Minute Empire: Legends is a quick game that implements the Civilization/Exploration theme using card-driven area control (by placing armies and cities in a small map) and set collection (by getting abilities from the cards). Players spread through the map in order to collect points at the end of the game by having majorities in regions and continents. All actions (such as land or sea movement, army production, or the founding of cities) are driven by cards that are face-up (six at a time) and available by increasing prices. Cards also belong to sets, which also give points when the game ends if properly collected.

Experior is a 2-player game with minimalist rules and an emergent complexity.

The game is about a combat in a fantasy world between a Human and an Elf. A character can perform three types of attack (sword, bow or magic attack), and each attack can be strong, causing great damages, or quick, causing damages more often. The damage intensity depends on the experience in that type of attack. A successful attack increases the experience of the fighter in that type of attack.

SETUP
Players choose randomly who is the Human and who is the Elf.

In a common paper is written down the initial experiences for each type of attack and the initial number of wounds of both characters, as shown below. Another option is to print the board in the section files.

ELF 
Wounds: 0
Sword: 2
Bow: 3
Magic: 2

HUMAN
Wounds: 0
Sword: 3
Bow: 2
Magic: 2

ATTACK: TYPES AND MODALITIES
There are three types of attack: sword, bow and magic. For each of those there are two modalities: quick and strong.

So, each player has 6 cards for every possible attack: strong sword, quick sword, strong bow, quick bow, strong magic, quick magic.

You can print the custom cards in the images section. Another options is to use 6 cards, for each player, from an UNO game: two red cards with 1 and 3 values for quick sword and strong sword, two green cards with 1 and 3 values for quick bow and strong bow, two blue cards with 1 and 3 values for quick magic.

Winning order: sword beats bow, bow beats magic and magic beats swords.

TURN
Each player places a face down card in the middle of the table. When both cards are placed, they are revealed.

• With a successful quick attack, the opponent takes a number of wounds equal to the value of experience the winner has in that type of attack.
• With a successful strong attack, the opponent takes a number of wounds equal to the value of experience the winner has in that type of attack multiplied by 3.

After the opponent’s damaging, the winner increases his experience in that type of attack by one.

The winning order (sword > bow; bow > magic; magic > swords) determines who has done a successful attack. If both players chooses the same type of attack, the winner is who played a quick attack.

In case both players choose the same type of attack and the same modality, the player with less experience in that type of attack increases by one that type of attack and nobody takes any wounds. In case both players has the same amount of experience neither of them gain experience.

At the end of the turn, the two cards just played stay on the table, aside but in full view and unavailable for the next turn. At the end of the next turn, the new played cards will stay on the table, whereas the cards from the previous turn will return in the players’ hands.

END OF THE GAME
The game ends when one player reaches a number of wounds greater than or equal to 100. (The game is perfectly scalable, so players can choose any number of wounds as end condition.)

After that, players have to check who will get a bonus attack. Each player subtracts the value in his highest experience with the value his lowest experience. Who has the greater difference makes a number of wounds to the enemy equal to his highest experience multiplied by 3 (like a strong attack). If the differences are equal, whoever has less wounds gets the bonus attack..

The winner is the player with less wounds.

In Mob Town, 2-4 players take on the role of Mob Families vying for control of unique towns that build differently every time you play.

Of course you can’t control this town on your own (you wouldn't want to get your hands dirty after all) so enlist the help of some shady shysters any fan of the Mob genre would recognize: blue tinted Sharks, bolo-wearing Snakes, conniving Weasels, foxy Foxes and of course no good dirty Rats!

Expand your empire and defend your turf until The Law shows up to spoil all the fun. Scramble to add up points you’ve earned for each property you own, then pack up and get your tail out of town and on to the next one. After you and your “friends” compete over, the game is over and the player with the most points is declared the new boss of Mob Town!

Parrot Pile-Up is a pile of fun! Balance, nerve and a steady hand are required in this tropical-themed game of skill. Players carefully stack fruit and crates on a clumsy parrot's raft with a steady hand and give it a patient push to the next player. If the stack falls, the player doing the pushing gets more pieces. The first player to get rid of all his or her cargo wins! Difficulty can be moderated by tilting the raft or leaving it level to accommodate multiple levels of skill. Includes 1 parrot, 1 raft, 20 stacking pieces and 4 cards.

Cat & Chocolate: Blooming Days is a card game which follows the other games in the Cat & Chocolate series, only this time the theme centers on Japanese school life. Players are divided into two secret teams, with each player taking turns drawing an event card and describing how they manage to escape the situation using 1-3 item cards in their hand. All players then vote "Safe" or "Out", and if a majority votes in favor of the player's story he or she scores a point. At the end of the game teams are revealed, and the highest scoring team wins.

"You are a tiny faint whisper in the tiny mind of a tiny land hermit crab - let’s face it that’s really tiny. Still god-hood has to start somewhere and all that you can hope is that your influence will be strong enough to see your crab through its next three vital moults before your rival beats you to it with their crab."

A strategy game for 2 players (though it may work eventually for more).

The Game takes place on an area of Australian Mangrove Swamp divided up into hexagon shaped spaces. Each player takes the part of a Land Hermit Crab God guiding their chosen Land Hermit Crab through their life in order to be the first to be big enough to worship at the Crab Temple.

Each player rolls 4 d6s which determine direction of movement, distance, the nature of the god gift (usually food but sometimes a shell), and the area where the gift will drop. It is up to the player to decide which die will be carrying out which role.

The Game components (which include crab pictures in a photo frame, hermit crab playing pieces and the entire board) fit onto just 3 pages (2 if you have your own tokens). Compact rules (1 double-sided standard sheet) and an optional player's aid page are also available. The board is modular so as to enable easy storage.

From the oasis city of Palmyra, a first-century Roman province, Caesar wants to expand his sphere of influence. Under his orders, you are to send out your army to annex new lands and your censors to collect taxes. The player who fulfills these orders the best will become the new governor of the province of Palmyra. From time to time, when Caesar is especially impressed by your development, he may provide you with extra support.

Palmyra is a tactical tile-laying game with few rules and high tactical choices. By placing new land tiles and moving your army and censor, you earn new tiles and coins for the Roman Empire. The most important thing is to not be too greedy when collecting taxes; otherwise future income may become sparse. Additionally, don't let tiles placed by your opponents cut you off, or else you'll be forced to lose valuable time. When all of the 120 coins are collected, the game ends, and whoever has collected the most coins wins.

After a successful bank heist, you and your fellow thieves are laying low and enjoying the good life. Most of the cash has been hidden away, and the rest has been invested in businesses throughout the city. Everything is going according to plan until the police get a breakthrough in their investigation. Accusations are made, fingers are pointed, and after a heated argument, you decide to go your separate ways.
 Chaos ensues as the SWAT team is called in and start to close off the city’s exits. Your only choice now is to escape the city before it is completely locked down. But you need a plan — a good route that allows you to leave the city while recovering as much of the money as possible.
 You will need to call in some favors and hire the local gangs to create diversions. Bribing the Police would be a good idea too, but it isn't cheap. Disguises may help, but they don’t fool everyone. Setting the Police on the trail of your former colleagues will give you a better chance of escape, but the other thieves are thinking the same thing...
 Will you escape the city with the most money, or will the Police lockdown the city before you can escape?

In Escape Plan, players are the thieves, but they may influence the cops' moves every turn. The robbers move on a modular board trying to reach the best spots to recover their loot and escape from the city with more money than the other thieves. The cops are trying to thwart their escape plan — by force if necessary. The players play cards to aid their escape and slow the other players down. The players take actions that allow them to move and to engage gangs, mules, and snitches.

It contains asymmetric roles set by missions that players may achieve during the game while avoiding the police. The players' roles as thieves are individual with every player for themselves. In the end, only the player who escapes with the most cash wins.

The game design is influenced by great heist films.

The game consists of 40 Challenge cards. Each card has one Primary Challenge and three Bonus Challenges.
The challenges come in four types: 
1. Out on a Limerick --- Fill in the blank at the end of the limerick with the correct Greek or Latin prefix.
2. On the Road --- Identify the author of each imagined diary entry, and the work of fiction he or she comes from.
3. The Eschewbox --- Correct the grammatical errors. The number of such errors is in parentheses at the end of the challenge.
4. Rooted Out --- Replace the bracketed words in the challenge with one of the multiple choice answers. The bracketed words essentially are a definition of the answer.
Players take turns being the reader, with the other players, beginning in a clockwise direction from the reader, attempting to answer the Primary Challenge. The first player to answer correctly selects a bonus challenge. If he cannot answer it, then the next player gets a chance, and so on. Each correct Primary Challenge answer is worth two points, and each correct Bonus Challenge answer is worth one point. The first player to reach 10 points wins.

A box contains 150 double-sided cards, each in one of three colors. Each side shows three different words layered on top of one another. Two of the words are related to each other in some way.
Three cards --- one of each color --- are placed on the table. Players simultaneously try visually to separate the words on each card and then claim the card. Once all three cards are claimed, the claimer of each card states the three words and explains why one of those words does not belong. The first player to collect three cards of each color wins.

Cthulhu: The Great Old One is a Lovecraft-themed quick-play card game for 2 to 10 players.

Each player is dealt cards until all cards in the deck have been dealt. Each player then makes pairs from the cards that player holds, making either Matched Pairs or Linked Pairs.  Then each player, in turn, chooses one card at random from another player, in the hope of making more pairs. Players may choose to play one Horror or Cultist card at the end of their turn, after taking a card from another player, to cause an in-game effect.

Once all cards have been paired (other than The Great Old One), then all players add up their total scores based on the pairs they created. Matched Pairs are worth two points, Linked Pairs are worth one point; and having all four cards of a Linked set is worth 4 points, no matter what order you have the two Pairs in. Horror cards are worth one point during the scoring phase. The player who ends the game holding The Great Old One loses the game, all other players compare scores to determine the winner.

The Cultist card is a separate card which may be played instead of a Horror card at the end of a player's turn, and although it subtracts 1 point from the player's final score, if a player who has played the Cultist ends the game holding The Great Old One, they win the game!

Welcome to Dwarven Miner, a game that sends you underground to collect resources from a mine so that you can then use those resources to craft items for your patrons.

In the game, you'll roll six custom dice in a push-your-luck style to see what can be pulled out of the mine. Craft those resources into all types of gear, from armor to magic wands to mithril swords. Patrons – which range from warriors and rune singers to alchemists and chieftains – are great and powerful dwarves who have chosen you to outfit them on their adventurous, mystical, and often dangerous professions. Each of them will require you to craft different items – and once those items are made, you can then activate those patrons. Each will earn you points and reward you with a special ability that affects the game.

The first player to satisfy enough patrons to reach thirty points wins.

The Marketplace Race is a promotional game designed to sell the virtues of Digital Equipment Corporation's new (at the time) J-11 microprocessor, introduced in 1983.  While the purpose of the game is marketing, it is theoretically a playable game.  It's a basic spin-and-move game, with the spinner built into the board, but with interrupts along the path which all speed the player with the J-11 along while slowing down the player with the "Brand X" chip.  The first player to the Market Place wins!

Conspiracy Theory is a co-operative game in which 2-6 players will work together in an attempt to thwart the nefarious schemes of a global conspiracy to dominate the world.  Each turn, players will use their actions to travel the globe, attempt to uncover pieces of the conspirator's plots, and struggle to remove the conspiracy's insidious influence.  However, the forward march of the conspiracy is relentless, and each turn another plot will be hatched.

As the game progresses, the plots will begin to build on one another, gradually growing in potency as the conspiracy races toward its final conclusion.  If the players are able to reveal enough plots in time, they will be able to expose the conspiracy to the rest of the world!  They must, however, remain vigilant, as the reach of the conspiracy is long, and they may have planted a traitor within your midst.  If the traitor is able to complete their secret objective before being exposed, then the rest of the team may lose their only chance to save the world!

In Continental Express, players add train cars to their station in the hope of fulfilling objectives and maximizing the value of their secret contract. To start the game, each player chooses one of two contract cards dealt to them; these contracts require players to collect icons of a particular color or groups of like-colored icons or icons and company tokens of differing colors.

Players then take turns drafting cards from three face-up rows; the card on the end of each row costs nothing, the card in the middle costs $1, and the card closest to each of the three decks costs $2. Players start with no money, however, and the only way to get some is to draft it – but naturally that means you'll be forgoing other cards. If a player has train cars matching one of the three face-up objective cards, he can choose to discard those train cars and claim the objective – and since the objectives have the icons that satisfy contracts, you'll probably want to do that.

In addition to train cars and money, players can draft characters, taking the special action of a character when he drafts one. Actions include things like taking a train car of your choice from the card array, stealing all money from one player, and taking a company token of the color of your choice. The card decks also include two events, and those cards flush either the objective cards on display or the smaller cards that players draft.

When a player claims his fourth objective, each other player takes one more turn, then the game ends. Players tally the points scored for their contract (if any), their claimed objective cards, and any money still in hand. Whoever has the highest score wins!

A ladybug-themed action game for children.

Theme
The ladybugs want to reach the top of the flower! But they need the players' help and lots of crawling and flying practice to do so. Can you help your ladybug reach the top first?

Goal
Be the first to complete a flower by collecting stem cards and a blossom card.

Game play
Players decide on how tall they want the flowers to be, e.g. 4 stem cards tall. Stem and blossom cards are put in separate stacks, face down.
Players take turns taking the top card from the stem card stack. The active player looks at the task described on the back of the card and tries to complete the task. If he/she is successful, he/she gets to keep the card and puts it down in front of him/herself. If he/she fails, the card is returned to the bottom of the card stack.
If a player has collected the agreed-upon number of stem cards, he/she gets to take a blossom card instead.

The first player to have built a complete flower (consisting, in this example, of 4 stem cards and a blossom card) wins the game.

Tasks require gross and fine motor skills, eye-hand-coordination, concentration and observation skills and include: flipping the wooden ladybugs with one's fingers, guessing in which hand another player is holding the bug, stacking bugs on top of each other, throwing a bug with one's foot and catching it, throwing it over one's head and catching it, balancing it on one's head, elbow or shoulders, jumping with a bug on one's hand etc.
There are 3 joker cards that allow players to add a card to their flower without completing a task, and three bad luck cards that make you lose a part of your flower.

Salnave's war is Military, Economic and Political game that represents the event that occurred in Haiti form 1867 to 1870.  The period of Haitian history called Salnave’s war by some and The War of the Cacos by others saw Haiti split into three competing states and both brilliant naval strategies and inept anti-insurgency campaigns.

The intent of the game is to provide the simple rules, short to medium playing times, indirect player interaction and abstract physical components of a Euro-game and the simulation of strategic combat of a war game.

The game uses a Euro-game approach to simulate the interplay of economics, politics, and military action. This approach is tied to the specific places, personalities, and events of the Caco War to present a compelling way to play out the flow of this intriguing part of history. There are three major modes of play that allow players to follow the events of the war in close historical order, more loosely, or only as a general backdrop.

Karta doppio is an abstract game from the family of 4 rows. Material is 14 translucent cards in 1st edition, 16 translucent cards in the most recent edition, divided in 2x3 square cells with 3 colored dots of 2 colors and 3 free cells. Each player chose a color.

The aim of the game is to have the maximum of lines of 4 dots at the end of the game.

Each player receives half of the cards at the beginning. Cards are distributed randomly.

Each turn, a player plays one card to try to achieve a row.

Cells of Cards can be covered but only one time.

You have 2 options : you can play with a board (11x11) where some dots already printed on or without board. In the first case, placement is free on the board. In the second case the current card must touch or cover a card already played.

The Cuban missile crisis spins out of control in this new version of Bruce's acclaimed nuclear war fighting game system.
 Using historically accurate strategic (ie Nuclear) force structures the players will be responsible for fighting the war on a global scale when the diplomats fail.

Rather than concern themselves with the operations of Army Corps and Naval Task Forces, players will be directing the B-52 bomber wings of SAC or the Strategic Rocket Forces new SS-7 “Saddler” ICBM’s.

Of course the new Soviet missile complexes on Cuba still retain their importance as a dagger aimed at the heart of the USA and will have to be factored into both sides plans. The surprise potential of these weapons are accounted for in the radar rules.

First Strike '62 is a hex-and-counter wargame. Units have movement points and move across a global map. Players select Operating Programs/Warplans to determine targets for their bomber, submarine and missile assets. Then they attempt to have those units reach their targets while avoiding opposing interceptors, ASW and anti-missiles. The "winner" is the player who scores the most victory points, based on strategic targets hit, surviving assets, and collateral damage received.

Your parents have given each of their children a part of the family farm in the small but growing town of Cottonwood. You have three years to show that you can make your share profitable. You may plant corn and grain, raise animals, and gather berries and herbs from the countryside. You may sell goods at each of the three Markets, and enter the income in your ledger. The sibling who has the most money in their ledger after the third year wins the contest, and will receive the remainder of the family farm. [Source: rules]

In The Cottonwood Contest, players develop their farms by plowing fields, planting corn and grain, building pastures, raising animals, weaving baskets, and gathering herbs and berries. Double-ended farm cards depict the choices for what the farmers may do with their day.

There are three scoring phases, triggered by drawing a market card. Prices for each item fluctuate, and players must determine the best time to sell their items. Corn and grain may be sold, or used to raise sheep and cows. Players may sell the wool from their sheep and the milk from their cows, or the sheep and cows themselves. Players may sell berries and herbs, or make the berries into jam and dry the herbs to sell at a later market.

The player who has the most money in their ledger after the third market is the winner.

Palestina under Davidstjernen is a 1950s boardgame themed on the Jewish rights to settle in the promised land of Palestine ("Kanaans land", "Jews land"). Players move their token on a classical 50s map of Palestine, and scores points as they reach different cities and locations on the map. Winner is the player with highest score after 30 minutes.

Players move on the board from directions given by the David star; players spin the David star, mounted on a large paper clip, each turn, and move on the board accordingly, as the David star tells you both which direction to go, and how far you should go. The rule book states where this location is mentioned in the bible, and how many points you get from entering this location.

Advanced version is to point in what part of the Bible this location is mentioned. The game is in Norwegian.

'Hijack the Revolt is a quick game of calculated risk, cooperation and backstabbing for three players.

Throughout history rulers have treated their subjects badly enough for the populous to rise up against them. Though joined momentarily in their common effort to overthrow the tyrant, the rebellious forces are comprised of factions having different visions of what their new country should be. Only one of those ideals will win out, and only then if they can remain united long enough to make their rebellion a success and avoid execution.

Hijack the Revolt is a cooperative game, up to a point. In this game of urban warfare there are four objectives which the three rebels must take before the Dictator sends reinforcement. They are Communications,  Munitions,  Airport, Presidential Palace. The game proceeds by each player in their turn playing a road taking tile to move them forward. You  have farther to go than the Dictator who advances automatically at the end of each turn. The only way to take an Objective is to coordinate your assault as you advance block by hard won block  But only one of you can win each round. When is the timing right for striking out on your own?

Like the game Risk boiled down to its most excruciating 20 minutes.

From the Back Cover:

During the period of 1600 to 1800 infamous pirates including Blackbeard, Captain Kidd, Anne Booney and Henry Morgan RAIDed ships and coastal towns in the Caribbean. Speed, cunning, surprise, determination, stalking one's prey, ambush, counter attack, fearlessness and ruthlessness characterized the RAIDs of these buccaneers.

The new Caribbean word game - RAID - recaptures the excitement, thrills, and anticaption of those bygone days.

RAID is a game for 2 - 6 players or teams. Play consists of forming words from the exposured blocks. Triple bonus points are earned by forming the name of any Caribbean country (a list is provided).

For example, Player one forms the word "cub" from the exposed blocks. Player two adds an A to form a new word "cuba". This is a RAID. Player two has formed the name of a Caribbean country Cuba, and so is awarded triple bonus points.

Girl Scouts & Guides game "WORLD-O, ohé! le monde". "A game on the world association of girl guides and girl scouts".
Players taking question cards and try to answer questions (answer cards shows the right answer) about scouting. The player at the end (then no more question cards left) with the most amount of answered questions win the game.

During the Wiener Spielefest, "Spieleberater"  move around to   explain games to the visitors.

Simple cooperative game for kids: Move any pawn, but not the one moved by the previous player and not the one actually forbidden to the next hidden tile. Reveal it (it shows a part of a board game) and place it onto the appropriate picture. If you pass a clock symbol by moving, add 1 hour on the clock. All children win if completed all games before 9 "game hours".

advanced competitive game for families: In addition, all players start with movement points they spend during their turn.  If a  player adds a picture tile, he will get 3 or 5 victory points (by chance). Moving tiles not spent count 1 victory point at the end in addition.

Was added to a description of recommended games available in Austria

Match the colors and be the first busy shopper to collect everything on your shopping list!

Each player selects a shopping list and a shopper playing piece.  24 cardboard grocery item tokens are placed on their matching spaces on the board.

On each turn, the player spins the spinner and moves his shopper to the next matching colored space on the gameboard path.  If the player lands on a space next to an item on his shopping list, he takes that item from the gameboard and puts it on his shopping list card.  Bonus moves include a Free Coupon space and spinning on Bananas Gorilla or Sergeant Murphy.

The first player to get to the checkout space with all the items on his list is the winner.

A Game of Rhyming and Poetry based on the books of Dr. Seuss.

Players roll one die and move a communal pawn around the game board.  When a player lands the mover on a "Rhyme" or "Poem" space, he draws a "Rhyme" or "Poem" card and completes the actions shown on the card.  The card actions include word play activities like: Name four words that rhyme with "cat"; Make up a four-line poem about the sea.

If a player completes an action correctly, he moves his colored Hat marker a certain number of spaces towards the multi-colored Hat in the center, then back out again towards his own colored Hat space.  The first player to return his Hat to its starting space wins.

"Control Tower" is a family boardgame about the management of the planes in an airport.
The players are air controllers who must land and take off the planes and distribute those planes in the diferent areas of the airport like repair/maintenance garage or refuelling to satisfice their requeriments.

The game has three phases. Twice of them are played simultaneously the makes the game very agile and exciting. The players feel the tension and anxiety that makes them quick decisions about the suitables planes.

"Control Tower" is addictive boargame for 1 to 4 players, with easy rules but complex making decisions.


"Torre de Control" es un juego de mesa familiar sobre la gestion de aviones en un aeropuerto.
Los jugadores encarnan a controladores aereos de la gestion interna de un aeropuerto y entre sus funciones estan ordenar los aterrizajes y despegues de los aviones y las distribucion de los aviones en los diferentes servicios del aeropuerto tales como  repostaje y reparacion y mantenimiento.

El juego se divide en tres fases. Dos de ellas se juegan de manera simultanea dandole al juego vitalidad y ritmo que hace que los jugadores se involucren y sientan la tension y el agobio de la continua llegada de aviones al aeropuerto con distintas necesidades a satisfacer.

"Torre de control" es un juego adictivo de 1 a 4 jugadores, de reglas muy sencillas pero con mucha toma de decisiones.

Publisher Blurb:

Cow Tipping is America's second favorite sport (only to fishing) and this fun stacking game has it all. 18 adorable, stackable cows, just waiting to be stacked and tipped. The goal is not to be the one to make the stack fall.

From Publisher's Introduction:
"Timeline 300 is a tabletop wargame, designed to be played between two or more players, that uses collectable miniatures which are intended to be built, painted, and personalised by each player so that she can construct a personal army of her (or perhaps, his) very own. Your tactical skill, and a random factor determined by the roll of dice, shall decide who wins your own “wars that never were”.

The game depicts a Martian invasion of earth during steam technology era.  Players generate resources from specific units (such as mining units) each turn that can be used to 'purchase' combat units for use in the battle portion of the game.  It simulates the type of action found in many real-time-strategy (RTS) games where resources and facilities help guide what type of forces each player can bring to bear.

In The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers Deck-Building Game, players take on the role of Frodo, Legolas, Aragorn, or one of their brave and heroic allies in the struggle against the forces of the Dark Lord Sauron! While you begin armed only with basic combat maneuvers, you'll add new, more powerful cards to your deck as you go, with the goal of defeating the deadly forces that serve Sauron as you make your way towards Mount Doom.

While The Two Towers can be combined with Cryptozoic's The Fellowship of the Ring Deck-Building Game, it's also playable on its own, and unlike that previous game, it includes a "Wall of Helm's Deep" deck that adds a new element to gameplay. If The Wall can't defend the wall from Saruman's forces and it becomes breached, the battle will get tougher for the heroes!

Cryptozoic's The Lord of the Rings/The Hobbit deck-builder series:


     The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring Deck-Building Game
     The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers Deck-Building Game
     The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King Deck-Building Game
     The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey Deck-Building Game
     The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug Deck-Building Game Expansion Pack

An expansion to the creativity game Rory's Story Cubes.  This set includes 3 new dice with 18 thematic actions.

This expansion can be played on it's own or in combination with the original game.

The game is useful as an aid to creative problem solving, language learning and story telling.  Players roll the dice and then tell a story using the actions.  "Once upon a time..."

Great minds think ... alike? outside the box?  
Can you think as a group or by yourself?  Can you confound the group into choosing something different?

This is a light-hearted fun little party game.  Players are trying to guess what the majority of the group will think and choose that answer, or choose something that others will not choose.  Whomever has the most points over several rounds is the winner.

On a round the active player:
- selects one of their cards and reveals it to the group
(the cards have several options listed e.g. cat, mouse, cheese)
- forms a phrase/sentence/question about that card
- reveals the "goal" card (which indicates "alike" or "outside of the box")

Players then try to select the best answer according to the "Group Goal" card.  If "alike" is revealed, they are trying to be in the group with the majority of guesses, if "outside of the box" is revealed, they are trying to not be in the group with the majority of guesses.
  
The inspiration of this game was to make a silly little fun filler, that was portable that would provide lots of laughter, while allowing players to come up with creative statements of their own.

A game of hat tricks, F.A. Enquiries, penalty appeals, and last minute goals.
Home and away matches against all the other players.
The Double is a game of chance, tactics and cunning.
Good players will win the Premiership.
Great players will win the double. The Premiership and the F.A.Cup.
Which will you be?

Players (2-4) represent football teams vying to win the double of the Premiership, and the F.A.Cup. Each player represents either Blue (City), Yellow (County) Green (Rovers) or Red (United) and takes a corresponding coloured token and six sided dice. Players start at the bottom of the league table and a fixture card is drawn. Both players roll their dice with the winner moving up the table 3 places or 1 place if the result is draw. The board is divided into 5 zones forming from the bottom The relegation zone, danger zone, mid table, and European places. Each time a player passes into a new zone a tactic card is drawn which can used and played to affect the results of matches. The home team of each match can re-roll his result dice, but has to take that result of the re throw.
The winner of the premiership has the advantage of choosing the draw for the F.A. Cup and has a one goal advantage on his throw, but tactic cards cannot be used by the players in the F.A. Cup.

Moby Dick, or, The Card Game is an adventure card game designed for 2-4 players, with additional rules for solitaire play. Based on Herman Melville's classic novel, Moby Dick combines cooperative and competitive play in an attempt to loosely simulate life on a 19th century whaleship.

The game is centered around three decks of cards: the Sea, the Sailor, and the Whale. After receiving an initial crew of sailors, players take turns at the topmast, where they draw Sea cards to advance the game. These cards contain various creatures and events, compelling actions between players or triggering the secondary phase of the game – the whale hunt. During a whale hunt, each player begins by choosing a small group of their sailors to lower after the whale. Play progresses much like the primary gameplay, with players taking turns defending against the whale's assaults and returning the favors.

As the game unfolds, players gain oil from defeating whales or from certain events, which can be used to hire new sailors after others are lost at sea. Over time, key events (Chapters) will be drawn, and after a certain number Moby Dick will cease evading the ship and engage when sighted. This last battle is to the death, and only one player will survive. Call him the winner, or simply, Ishmael.

Game for two players. The board represents a city where players must steal atomic energy projector the other player. The movement is done by the adjacency board, eliminating the pieces depends on the type to which they face.


Juego para dos jugadores.El tablero representa una ciudad donde los jugadores deben robar un proyector de energia atómica del otro jugador. El movimiento por el tablero se hace por adyacencia, la eliminación de las piezas depende al tipo a las que se enfrenten.

Welcome to AMBIGUITY, the head-spinning letter-turning word game. The Goal: Roll the eight letter dice into the tray and turn over the two minute timer. Now the fun begins because the letters on these dice are ambiguous and represent several different letters depending on how you turn your head to view them. Quickly study the "face-up" letters, without moving them, and write down as many words as you can spell, Players earn points for word length. The first player to score 100 points wins. So what are you waiting for? Get ready for some head-spinning fun.

A educational/trivia game about electrical power.

Pull a power card and answer a question determined by the color of the card. Answer correctly and move 1 to 3 spaces on the board. Follow directions on board space if any (move forward/back). Answer incorrectly and loose turn.

Winner is first person to land on or pass their starting space.

Introduction
TOPOLO is a 2 player abstract game that is played on the spaces of an 8x8 grid.

The Red player and the Black player have 32 cuboid pieces in 3 sizes(16 small pieces worth - 1 points apiece, 8 mid size pieces worth - 2 points apiece and 8 large pieces worth 3 points apiece).

Objective
Assemble your pieces into the largest orthogonally adjacent group to win.

Definitions

Group – Like color 1 or more orthogonally adjacent pieces.

Play
At the start of the game the board is empty.

The player holding the Red pieces plays first.

The row on the board closest to the Red player is considered row 1 followed by rows 2,3,4,5,6,7,8.

The Red player may place any one of his pieces onto any empty space on the board, then its Black's turn. Thereafter play alternates.

Example:
If the Red player has placed his first piece onto an empty space on the board that is within an even numbered row then both players must then play onto all the empty spaces of the even numbered rows first before proceeding to fill the empty spaces of the odd numbered rows. Now if the Red player plays his first piece onto any empty space of an odd row then both players must play onto all of the remaining empty spaces of the odd rows before moving play to the even rows.

The game ends when the board is full.

Scoring
Your score is determined by counting the pieces within the largest Group. Each piece within these Groups are to be counted as 1 point apiece, irrespective of their individual heights.

The player with the highest score is the winner.

In the event the largest Groups of both players are the same size at end game, each piece within these Groups are to be counted by their individual height point values (small - 1,medium - 2 and large - 3)and added to determine a winner.

For subsequent draws look at the next largest Groups of each player and apply the same scoring rules.

From the back of the box:
"Welcher Hase ist der Schnellste? Bei der wilden Möhrenjagd gewinnt derjenige, der als erster das Möhrenbeet erreicht hat. Lustiges Würfelspiel für Klein und Groß, ideal als Mitbringspiel oder für die Reise."

Translation:
"Which rabbit is the fastest? A game of "Rabbit eating Raddish" will be won by the rabbit that reaches the raddish bed first. A funny dice game for every age. Perfect as a small gift or to play during travel."

Summary of gameplay:
"Rabbit eating Raddish" is a 2 player roll and move game. Each player takes two rabbits of the same colour and places them at the start in tandem. The raddish bed is placed on the table 50 cm away from the start. On his or her turn a player will roll the six-sided die and move the rabbit in the back ahead of the front rabbit as often as the die says. The player who reaches the raddish bed first is the winner.

Fútbol Strategy gives you teams of 12 footballers that share the same nationality to pick the six stars you want to build a game plan around and contest a fast, strategic, and fun version of the beautiful game against your opponent.

Move your stars into different spaces in their defense, middle, or attacking thirds. Search for space on offense while cover and closing down on defense. The action cards resolve play and serve as the game clock, referencing one of the six unique ratings that each of your footballers have, making each unique and interesting to play. Pass, shoot, clear, and tackle. Futbol Strategy has realistic rules for corner kicks, free kicks, and penalty kicks while remaining sleek and easy to play.

Midway through the first game both players will be very comfortable with the system. Games then will play in just 30 minutes despite offering interesting strategic decisions in the beginning and tense tactical decisions throughout.

How high can you roll without rolling a one? The more you roll, the higher you score, the higher you score the faster you win. But, watch out that you don't roll any ones or you will lose your points and be required to pay a poker chip to the pot. The ultimate game of risk-taking and pushing the limits.

Come and enjoy our cute, cutthroat, family friendly, card game where our dragons will...

Welcome you to the high fantasy world of Vallhyn. You will roam the countryside in search of treasure because you are a dragon — a young dragon, that is. You and your friends have just been kicked out of the nest for eyeing your parents' treasure hoards. The problem with being young is that you don't always succeed in your quest to find treasure, which often leads to havoc. To make matters worse, you must compete for the best loot with your friends by engaging in hijinks.

Havok & Hijinks is a fast-paced, light strategy card game that pits you against your friends in a race for the first respectable treasure hoard. Each turn starts with a quest for treasure that could lead to Havok like loot-hungry adventurers or beneficial heat waves. Engage in Hijinks by stealing and breaking your friend's shiny treasures or defending your own. When a dragon has a hoard with a value of 15 or more, it wins!

Game Play

Start your turn by flipping a Havok Card

     Resolve any event flipped exactly as the card reads
     Add any treasure flipped to your hoard


Once you've resolved your Havok card you may play one Hijinks card
You may also use your dragon's play ability

You may choose not to play a Hijinks card and instead discard one to draw one

Pass your turn

In IncrediBrawl, each player guides a colorful cast of characters from all corners of the imagination as they meet in an epic clash for glory! Summon the right characters at the right time to outwit your opponents; use whatever strategy you can muster to overcome the randomness of the brawl! Amass the most glory along the way to become the ultimate champion in this crazy contest of luck and wits!

For basic gameplay, players shuffle their deck and draw five cards to start the game. Each player simultaneously selects a character from his hand and plays them face down at the current location. Once all the players have selected their characters, flip over the cards to begin the brawl!

After triggering any abilities revealed by the flip, players then compare their power type and power levels to determine who wins each scrap and the overall brawl. The winner gains one Glory (VP), plus activates any abilities their character may have that trigger off of winning. Each player then discards the played character, and draw one new card before the next round begins. The first player to reach ten Glory wins the game!

Each card in IncrediBrawl has a unique ability, and each player will start the game with a copy of the same set of cards. Choosing which character to play and what ability to trigger at just the right time is key to collecting the most Glory and winning the game!
